top_comment.text:
Seriously I mean no disrespect, but looking at 3:33 I can't say the result 
is looking very good. Even at the not very high detail offered by the video 
I can see how jagged and uneven the black sealer lines are. Why not use a 
transparent sealer instead or at least take better care with the masking 
tape and mask the aluminum frame too? Doing what you do, I trust you are 
professionals, but this looks amateur at best. If I owned that car, I'd 
have been very unhappy.﻿
top_comment.author: Iguana93

comments.text:
+HD2512DK Thanks! But yeah, I was wondering about that myself... Not really 
a good, lasting repair there!
comments.author: TheFurriestOne

you have to remove the chrome trim

That was a tune off for me to... you have to remove the list to put sealer 
in...
comments.author: HD2512DK

captions.text:
00:01
COMM: Master craftsman Lance McCormack owns

one of Britain's best classic car restoration
businesses, 'Romance of Rust'. Helping him

manage it is his son Merlin, the cutting edge
sales man who also runs his own classic car
dealership together they turn 'Rust To Riches'.

00:21
COMM: Today's project is a very special ferrari,
which is delivered by Merlin.

00:26
MERLIN: The car we've got here is a 1956 Ferrari

250 GT, long wheel base Tour de France 14
Louvre its a bit of a mouthful. This car was

actually part of Disney at one point you might
recognise it from the love bug, um where it

was sadly defeated by Herbie, its a very important,
historic car, the flamboyant Italian stallion.

00:48
LANCE: this would have looked very grubby

at some point in its life and this car at
some point in its life would have been tens

of thousands now we are talking about ten
million plus, my own personal insurance would
go up if I touch it.

01:03
LANCE: Its quite basic there is a bucket seat

aspect to it. We got the 14 Louvres here and
its alluminium to get that line in the middle

double curved panel is quite difficult these
are real crafts mans these guys, Borrani they

are like the Gucci of wheels, they are painted
in silver but you could have the shiny but

it just shows the competition history its
more about fresher and delivery of the power,

look at this little device here, the leather
is worn to almost the point of a tear but

that there shows you what lies beneath in
the soul of this car and its nice that someone's

preserved this so the leather hasn't got a
single drop of lamening left in it, in fact

a few more times open and closed in there
is going to be history

01:44
COMM: Now that the car is being driven in

British weather, its been discovered that
the windscreen is letting in the rain.

01:50
LANCE: Its been in America for a while, probably

California so probably no issue with it being
a water tight and its not good for the car,
not good for the business.

01:58
COMM: As Lance's main expertise lies in metal

work, he has called in some help for this
job, windscreen expert Phil who's noticed
something concerning

02:07
PHIL: There is a big scratch in the glass

that has been polished out so its got a little
bit of a weak point so I'm going to try desperately

hard not to take this out of the insitue,
its extremely rare to take this apart.

02:18
COMM: Normally the team would carefully remove

the windscreen and clean up the metal work
and remove the odd seal before re-fitting

and re-sealing it, but the particular potential
weak point means Phil wont want to risk far
worse damage.

02:31
LANCE: If you took it out a broke it we are

in big trouble here and it will be a nightmare
shift of that happens.

02:35
PHIL: You cant really talk and do, I mean

you can watch but I better carry on and not
talk any more because I don't want to slip
and damage the paint.

02:45
COMM: Phil uses a range of tools to attack

the seal but one slip of his hand can cause
damage of tens of thousands.

02:52
LANCE: A lot of care is taken here to remove

the old sealer that has been put in layer
upon layer, we try to waterproof it.

02:59
COMM: Once the old seal is cut away, Phil

applies masking tape to protect the screen
when the new seal is added.

03:04
LANCE: What we do here is a very careful even

bead that will go around here and when its
finished it just looks like its a bead there
and thats what this man does very well.

03:17
COMM: And now for the moment of truth, Phil

carefully peals away the protected tape to
reveal the newly sealed windscreen. With the

work successfully completed, the ferrari is
now ready to be returned to its owner.

03:30
LANCE: Its a very important, historic car

and its now in the hands of someone that does
it proud.

03:42
COMM: Next time on Rust to Riches, business

is booming and Merlin has ambitious plans
to expand.

03:48
MERLIN: Stuff coming in and selling faster

than I could even dream of is great for me
but it means that I'm constantly searching

for new stock, which is a big struggle, everybody
and their brother thinks they can be a classic
car dealer and the competition is fierce.

title: Episode 2: The Ten Million Pound Ferrari - Rust To Riches
